I-1.title: Hurting Others
I-1.searchTitle: Free Kids' Short Stories | Managing Anger
I-1.searchDescription: Online books that teach kids from 4 to 9 years old how to deal with anger and big emotions.  Kids love the 'choose your own story' format!
I-1.bookTitle: Best Kids' Books for Dealing With Anger
I-1.bookDescription: These top rated children's stories help kids learn to manage their anger, control their emotions, and not hurt others.

references.title: The Foolproof Way to Keep Your Child From Hitting Other Kids
When Your Child Hits Your Other Child

When Your Child Hits You: A Script

Stop Aggressive Behavior in Kids and Tweens

Children’s Anger Management Strategies That Work

How to Help Kids Manage Anger
When Your Child Gets Angry: The Cheat Sheet
How to Raise an Emotionally Healthy Child
When Your Child Gets Angry: Here's Your Gameplan

importantInformation: Kids hurting each other sometimes is normal.  Kids often learn to stop hurting others on their own.

Yelling, punishing, or spanking won't prevent future violence.  These actions scare children, which halts their learning.  To prevent violence, kids need to learn about the consequences of hurting others, what to do instead, and the benefits of picking better options.
Kids can't learn when they are upset.  Immediately after an event happens, focus on comforting both kids and helping them recover.  Save the teaching for later.
learningGoals: Getting mad is okay - we all get mad sometimes!  But sometimes when we are mad, we feel like hurting someone else.  Hurting others is never okay.

There is always a better choice than hurting someone else.  We can get away from what is making us mad or find a way for everyone to be happy.  If we hurt others, we won't get what we want and other kids won't want to play with us.

Being mad doesn't feel good.  We can have more fun when we aren't mad.  We get mad when something doesn't go our way.  But that happens to everyone!  Things go wrong all the time.  If we remember that things go wrong sometimes, we won't feel so mad when they do.

C-1.title: Critical Thinking
C-1.searchTitle: Free Kids' Books to Read Online | Critical Thinking
C-1.searchDescription: Online books that teach kids from 4 to 9 years old the importance of critical thinking.  Kids love the 'chose your own story' format!
C-1.bookTitle: Best Kids' Books for Teaching Critical Thinking
C-1.bookDescription: These top rated children's stories help kids learn to think critically, be open-minded, and think for themselves.

references.title: Teaching Children to Think
How to Learn Critical Thinking
15 Things We Have Learned About Critical Thinking
5 Tips for Critical Thinking
5 Barriers to Critical Thinking
Teaching Children to Think
How Children’s Brains Learn to Reason
Your Deceptive Mind: A Scientific Guide to Critical Thinking Skills
Why Don't Students Like School?: A Cognitive Scientist Answers Questions About How the Mind Works and What It Means for the Classroom

importantInformation: We aren't born with thinking skills, but develop them through practice.  To develop these skills, kids need the space to think for themselves and come up with their own ideas.

Telling kids what to think, giving them all the answers, and solving all their problems for them prevents them from practicing their thinking skills.  Let kids know they are free to come up with their own ideas and change their minds.  Ask them questions about what they think and why.
learningGoals: Something can seem true, when it really isn't.  Believing something that isn't true can cause us to make bad choices.
Don't believe something just because someone says it.  Think about what makes sense to you and check things out for yourself!  It's okay not to be sure.  Nobody knows everything.

The things advertisements tell us aren't always true.  Advertisements are just trying to get us to buy stuff.  Advertisements make things sound better than they really are, which can trick people into buying things they don't really want.

S-1.title: Honesty
S-1.searchDescription: Read short stories online for kids from 4 to 9 years old.  Kids get to choose what happens in the story, and learn the importance of honesty along the way!
S-1.bookTitle: Best Kids' Books for Teaching Honesty
S-1.bookDescription: These top rated children's stories help kids understand the benefits of honesty and the consequences of lying.

Teaching Your Kids to Be Honest

importantInformation: Almost all kids start experimenting with lying around the age of 2 or 3.  Almost all adults lie as well.  Lying to spare the feelings of others or conceal private information is actually an important skill for adults to have.
Establish the value of honesty in your family.  Discuss the benefits of honesty.  Explain that certain kinds of lying, like lying to spare someones feelings, are actually okay.
Sometimes telling the truth is hard.  Make it safe to be honest by avoiding the use of punishments and praising difficult truth telling.
learningGoals: Trust is when we know someone will tell the truth.  Trust is when we know someone won’t hurt us or our stuff.  It feels good when other people trust us. It feels good when we can trust other people.

Sometimes we might feel like lying to hide something we did wrong or get something we want.  Bad things almost always happen when we lie.  Other people won't trust us and lies grow bigger.  When we are honest, people trust us and like us more.
